title: Sphere II
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
is a multi color spherical mood light. 29 WS2812 breakout boards are mounted inside a opal glass shade.
I have uploaded a little video, showing Sphere II in action.

In addition to the printed parts you'll need
  • 01 x Spherical lamp shade
  • 29 x WS2812 breakout boards
  • 58 x screws M2x6
  • 57 x 1x3 pin header (makes soldering easier)
  • 04 x servo cables (~20cm)
  • 1 x Arduino, Teensy or what ever µController you like.

comments.text: If anyone is curious, the best software to control this sphere in my opinion is Glediator. It supports these WS2812 LED's, and can display a variety of different patterns if that is your thing. It works with Java and is compatible with every OS, though I haven't been able to get it to work with my Mac. Still, it's worth it to have a look. http://www.solderlab.de/index.php/software/glediator
comments.author: Saaif88

comments.text: Do you happen to have the code that you used for the video example? I haven't been able to find a replica of it.

i have the code and i'll prepare a repository on github in the next view days.

comments.author: Spirou

comments.text:
Hi NoLiver92, It was not so pricy as you expected.
The Lampshade was from a very inexpensive lamp from a shop like "Home Depot" and was about 10-15 €.
The most expensive part here are the WS2821 breakout boards which cost 6.5€ for a strip of 5 adding up to 39€ for the 29 LEDs alone.
If you go with strips like http://ledsee.com/index.php/new-products/1m-ws2812b-black-strip-60-leds-per-meter-detail you will get 60 LEDs for 14€

comments.text: PLA printed on your new mini?
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: No, the mini has been quite temperamental, and we are working to get it running smoothly. This is on my new Replicator 2x modified to print PLA.
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text:
1) Bummer on the mini. thought in the hands of someone technical like you it would be a snap.
2) If I had a 2x, no PLA would foul it! (sorry ABS snob here(heh))
seriously looks real nice, assumed the mini as it is PLA optimized.
comments.author: Hatch

comments.text:
1) No worries! Im working with them and we will get it in order very soon. The unit for the contest had not gone through the full QC process, so naturally there are just a few glitches, some being smart extruder related. I do have some tweaks that made it a bit better, but I'm hoping to use them once its back online for some great stuff including some mods!
2) and haha, I know you are a pro with ABS; its hard to shy away from the results of the acetone polish results you've been getting. Once you tame ABS you really don't want to look back. I've got my 2x modded to print PLA mostly for the excess I poses, and because I have a few machines confined to a small bedroom.
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: What kind of mods have you done to get it printing pla well? It's kinda hit and miss with mine. Heat creep on that thing is a killer.

title: Prusa i3 Rework - Reworked Y Axis Motor Mount and End Stop

description.text:
When I installed the motor mount on my Prusa i3 rework, the motor
was twisting a bit from the pull of the belt, and the end stop was not
where I wanted it. So I modded the motor mount to include a separate motor mount, a
motor support, and a separate end-stop with vertical
mount.

title: Motor bracket for 37mm diameter gear motor

description.text: I made this bracket to hold a motor that is available on eBay.  The motor has a 37mm diameter face mount, is geared, and has an offset output shaft.  The motor fits in and allows you to mount it to a flat surface parallel to the output shaft.  You can make adjustments to the motor position (for example for belt tension adjustment) by twisting the motor on its face.  The slotted mounting holes allow you to tighten the motor in a variety of positions.  Caveat:  I designed this motor mount while I was waiting for the motor to arrive from China based on dimensions in the eBay description.  It is NOT a perfect fit.. But it does work.  We use this motor to turn the "licker" of a drum carder for processing wool fiber.  But it could be used for 1000s of projects such as robotics, home automation, valve control etc.  The small DC motors are under $20USD on eBay. Enjoy.

description.text:
A fix on a student's 3D-ification of part of the MakerBot Plastruder. Here's my fixes: 1: Used the Blender command "remove doubles" to get rid of what looks like about 3000 extra vertices, and re-calculated normals for good measure. (Both steps are always a good idea when working with stuff made from CAD files.)
2: Scaled up by ten-- I think this model may have been done at 1 Blender Unit per centimeter when the scale for skeinforge is 1 Blender Unit per millimeter.

comments.text:
I actually drew this part on Autodesk's Inventor, it's a pretty sophisticated program so i didn't think it would give me any problems with the vertices, thanks for the fix though i really appreciate it. Love the support.
Matt. 8-)

Miniature oven Given away for a pre-Christmas party An oven with accessories
The oven has turntable knobs, light and can be opened
the accessories are: 2 pizza's (with salami, pinaple, mushrooms and bacon strips.) and a margarita, a plate for in the oven and a pan (and fire). it's way too fragile to let children play with this!

made with 4mm wood
file contains 10 20cm * 40cm artboards. Key to build this oven is patience, try and error and when you sure it fits then glue it, not glue it and later test if it's correct or not. It is made as a onetime thing and not at all as a user friendly build design . Smaller parts not correct put together can be unable to interlock in bigger parts. it's basically an inner cube and a outer cube. order of building hint:
[inner cube] - bottom -> (oven plate guides + slide for the door -> sides) -> back -> top -> inner front -> door; [outer cube] - inner cube -> (battery compartment -> bottom) -> (knobs (and mind place for switch) -> front) -> electrical stuff -> (top+ 1 side) -> other side -> back (closed) Making the light work: electronic level: noob
2 led connected to 2 batteries with a switch in between, easy.
first test 1 led, if it works, make it double. 2 × white led lights, 2 × 3V button cells, 1 switch the color of the led makes a difference, 1 white led will do fine on a 3V button cell, other colors probably need a resistor. make both for the led and the batteries a tandem connection, series connection or a daisy chain, all of the same will work (Google it if none of it make sense, or if you realy don't know how to do this). the parts have a specific place and cannot fit the other way around.
The big interlocking tooth of the inner cube are in the front of the oven. the back, left and right side interlocks with the outer cube. the top of the inner cube has some support against the back of the outer cube but it is designed in a way that the last part of the outer cube is the back side of the oven (it would be hard to put together if it had interlocking tooth like sides and the bottom). the opening mechanism is a 3 layer system:
  • front leg of inner cube
  • 2 placeholder and slider
  • cover for slider
    little pieces line up the 3 layers
    (and some parts that are useless, and should hold the door closed but it works fine without this, it are 4 pieces on the same artboards as the opening mechanism cover for the sliders)

description.text:
"transform and roll out!"  
this model/miniature is designed after the Viking out of Starcraft 2 and can transform from a fighter to an assault/mech mode  
it's somewhat poseable in mech-mode, since the legs are ball-jointed... the rest sits on 1-DOF joints/pins... so don't expect to much posing from them :-P  
this is most likely not suited for small/young children since it's somewhat fragile... i'm targeting more all those grown-up/older kids out there who like to put toys on shelves for display ;-)

transform sequence (fighter -> assault):
  • unfold the legs
  • fold the fins on the wings
  • sweep back the wings
  • rotate and extend gattlings
  • in one motion rotate rear (with the wings) and lower rocket-pods (with gattlings attached)
  • push-back cockpit and lower attached frontal fins
  • enjoy :-D

prints well:
  • in PLA
  • with a 0.4mm nozzle
  • 0.1 or 0.2mm layer height
  • without (additional) support
    • the parts have an inbuilt clearence, but depending on the tolerances your printer produces expect to sand the parts around the joints for an optimal fit
recommended print settings:

(LH = layer height, IF = infill, SH = perimeter/shells):
rear: 0.1mm LH, 3 SH, 0 IF = hollow, print with raft
wing parts: 0.1mm LH, 8 SH
other parts: as you like :-) print one of each part, and a second mirrored copy for the wings, fins, legs, gattlings and rocked-pods as well as the backbone
(for the stand print either stand_B_1 or stand_B_2)
other things needed:

• ~1mm diameter wire for all the joints (i used small nails, sawn to length; paperclips also work)
  • short cylindrical piece with 3mm diameter (3mm filament :-) for the joint connecting the pelivis pin to the backbond (white filament in the picture)
  • glue to combine parts and secure pins in place
  • for the stand: a 8mm diameter acrylic rod
assembly:

• glue the two-part fin_fold_AB together, back to back
  • push gattling_D in gattling_B, and both in gattling_A
  • glue the limiter rings gattling_E to gattling_D; and gattling_C to gattling_B
  • assemble wings and fins with 3 wire-pins each (two for the fin, one to connect the wing to rear)
  • push both backbone and the body_mount parts in that order into the base (see picture)
  • both cockpit_fins cockpit and body_mount are held together wit one long pin
  • mount the (pelvis-)pin to the backbone with the 3mm rod - make sure its level with the backbone sides
  • mount rear (+attached wings) with one pin to the backbone
  • mount the gattling to the rocket-pod and that assembly to the base with wire-pins
  • pop ball-joints of the legs together, onto the pelvis and connect it to the rest
  • paint
    (hope i didn't forget anything... :-P)

Basic text renderer implemented as an OpenSCAD module, allowing the generation of text from a string directly in OpenSCAD.
Currently uses a HD44780 LCD controller dot matrix font.
Two versions exist, TextGenerator.scad covers all OpenSCAD versions before 2015.03. Version 2015.03 deprecated the assign module, allowing for more convenient C like assignments. Therefore I've created a new version removing the deprecated module warning generated by this version.

• Import module
  • call drawtext("string")

title: Solderdoodle Pro 2.0: USB Rechargeable Soldering Iron

description.text: Solderdoodle Pro 2.0 is a portable, cordless, USB rechargeable soldering iron with improved ergonomic grip and design. It is based off my original Solderdoodle Kickstarter project: http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/249225636/solderdoodle-pro-700of-usb-rechargeable-soldering Solderdoodle Pro does what other portable soldering irons have failed to do, and that’s the ability to last at full power for over a half hour above 800ºF, over 2 hours above 500ºF, and charge the soldering iron from a USB port. You can literally go anywhere and still have a way to charge your Solderdoodle if there is a laptop, USB battery, wall adapter, or even a USB solar charger nearby! Solderdoodle Pro uses a high-efficiency, high-power charge controller, uses the same battery that's used in the Tesla electric car, and uses replaceable tips.
Click below for instructions on how to build the Solderdoodle Pro prototype! http://www.instructables.com/id/Solderdoodle-Pro-20-USB-Rechargeable-Soldering-Iro/

description.text: GEAR BOX

Designed specifically for the Apple EarPods as supplied on the latest iPhones, including the inline mike/switch. For a wrapper that will work for other earbuds, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21858, and for a wrapper designed for older Apple earbuds, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13678.

The rear clip builds separately from the body and is glued to the back in the position shown.The .stl files are supplied as just the main body, as just the clip, and as the two combined. In my machine printing items separately results in less cleanup; your milage may vary.  
Start the wrap by dropping the EarPods in their respective holes (they only fit one way). Take the cables down under the top lip and to the left. Hook them into the left slot, up and over the EarPods, down through the top right slot and continue though the bottom slot. The mike should now lie across the back of the wrapper. Bring the cables down through the opposite slot and wrap the cables to the right and around the spool.  
When the cable reaches its end, the plug should be near the last slot on the rear. Hook the cable into the slot and snap the plug into its holder.  
Remove the plug by pushing on the metal end, grabbing it at the cable end, and pulling it out of its holder..

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8wP25bxgyzJ

Template for a 5.8 ghz helical antennas (up to 8 loops).
This template allready takes into account that the copper wire will bend back a bit. The measurements of the template are based on this calculater:
http://jcoppens.com/ant/helix/calc.en.php If you don't know what a helical antenna looks like or how to build one please search on youtube or google for more information Usage:
Take a straight 1 mm copper wire bend the first 5 mm to a right angle an stick it into the top hole. Than wrap the wire tight around the template. Allway bend a loop more than you actually nead. Now take your side cutter, cutt of the angle and turn the helix down the template. According to the calculater the reflector hast to be at least 32 mm in diameter.

title: Robox Filament Catcher (No longer works/needed with latest update)

description.text: The latest update seems to fix the problem of filament flicking everywhere by lowering the heads for the pre-print purge, so it seems this is no longer needed. Save time picking up filament that has flicked under the print bed with the Robox filament catcher. It catches the filament from the tip wipe blade every time you print. I have tweaked my original design to make the catcher stronger and easier to remove the filament. Designed for the CEL Robox. IMPORTANT: Be sure to clear the filament after every print to avoid problems.

It's best to print the catcher in ABS. Due to the higher temperature of ABS prints a PLA catcher can deform when handling it in them conditions whereas an ABS catcher will work with both materials. I printed it using the Robox fine setting and 100% fill. It takes about 10 min.

title: A Merry Marblevator Christmas Tree
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yes, yes, I know, yet another Marblevator (yawn), but this one is in Christmas Tree form and as an added bonus the track assembly, screw and marble lift housing prints in one piece! Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6fe9wRFAmWg&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA. Video of prototype in high speed track break in test here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7WtRruzbctw&index=2&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA The basic assembly consists of 5 components; "Track.stl", "Screw Lower.stl", "Screw Middle.stl", "Screw Upper.stl", and "Cap.stl" (I dissected the screw components for those with a limited build area). Optional accessories adding to the decor include "Star.stl" (never waste a PTO), "Ornament Ball.stl" and "Clip Ornament.stl". With "Clip Ornament.stl" and "Ornament Ball.stl", you can customize your Merry Marblevator Christmas Tree to your liking. I'm still working on some presents for under the tree and additional ornament styles, and my wife is sewing a skirt for the base, but I posted this for those who wanted to get a head start on printing this thing before, well you know, Christmas. Hence, the work in process status. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill). Merry Christmas! Oh, and thanks, Archimedes!

Parts I purchased: 1) 60RPM Speed Reducer Rectangle Shape N20# Magnetic Mini Geared Motor 6V DC (Amazon, http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AUCGJX0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1). 2) Coaxial Power Jack (Radio Shack part number 274-1583). 3) 3.0 Vdc Power Supply (Radio Shack part number 273-315 with the "N" style plug 273-345, you get one free with the power supply). 4) 14 or so "marbles" (8mm ball bearings purchased at a local Ace hardware store, also available on Amazon). You can use just one if you so desire, but 14 makes sure there are marbles on the track at all times if you want to run the motor at 6vdc. 5) Large rubber sticky feet (available at hardware and dollar stores). Study "Assembly.skp". Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp". Carefully remove the hold down pad on "Star.stl". If anyone has warping problems printing "Track.stl" (I've printed 6 without warping problems but I carefully trammeled the build plate with a feeler gauge before each print) I can add hold downs if required. Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. After assembly of the three screw pieces, I used the completed assembly as a "ream" of sorts to clean out the larger tube on "Track.stl". I also used a #2 pencil to clean out any tiny filament strings on the track surface of "Track.stl". By carefully cleaning the track, marble entry and exit points, and spine tubes will make sure your assembly operates properly. Assemble as per "Assembly.skp". Wiring is pretty straight forward and simple, however you'll need minimal soldering skills and soldering equipment. Basically, solder a 3" red wire between the gear motor "plus" terminal and the coaxial power jack "Center" terminal, then solder a 3" black wire between the gear motor "minus" terminal and the coaxial power jack "Shield" terminal. Comment if questions. Hope you like it, and Merry Christmas!!

comments.text: Thanks Greg, The entire column, that is the section which encloses the auger, from where it emerges from the motor housing right up to the top seems very fragile. description.text:
This was inspired by the Prusa i3 base plate. Changes:

  • Support for both LM8UU bearings with zip ties and pillow blocks (SC8UU)

  • Mounting holes for both ubiquitous PCB heatbed (MK1/MK2) and Helios heat bed with 3-point mounting. (104.75mm centers)

  • Added belt holder mounting holes closer to the dual bearing side.

Parametric Lego Round Brick.  
This is an approximation of Lego part-no 3062.

description.text:
USB braided wire holder :
This is a holder for the most popular chinese usb braided cable. This is a solution when you always let the wire in the same position and it tries to fallen down under the bed or the table.
First insert the wire then rotate it and finally pull it until the usb head fits perfectly into the gap, to remove reverse steps.
You can attach it to the wall or to your desk table with double side tape.
Don't need support, only print.
Actualization!! The same file but rotated.

title: Extruder Mount and Probe Mount for Phoenix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount (on the extruder) for a Phoenix 3D.
It is meant for use with an Inductive Probe Sensor. Please submit any issues with design (files) or improvement ideas in the comments section.

Renaming original design to z-probe mount (original).stl
Current (in-progress) design will have version numbers for easier tracking of changes.
I need your input, design ideas, etc.

I would love to design a whole new extruder assembly with z-probe built-in, but for now, this will have to do.
Once my printer is running good with the new mount (and the firmware is running good as well), all my attention will be focused on creating a new (single and dual) extruder assembly with a z-probe mount built in.

These instructions are for the original probe mount.
Instructions for the new mount will be included once design is final. ==============================================
Print as preferred (support or no support).
At least 40% infill, but you can get away with less. Slide in the wiring for the probe through the opening before soldering and wrapping your connectors for the RAMBo board.
Mount the probe on the probe mount (the thing you are looking at) before mounting on the extruder but don't tighten the probe yet.
Mount the probe mount on the left or right (front) side of the extruder motor with the same screw (just remove the washer). You want the bottom (sensor) of the probe to be about 1mm from the bed in relation to the extruder nozzle.

remixed_from.author: mgx
remixed_from.title: MOAB - MOther of All fan Brackets

description.text:
This Is a bracket I made for the Chinese RepRapDiscount Smart Controller LCD Interface that comes with some RAMPS kits.  
After trying a few solutions from other people here on thingiverse I couldn't get something that would work. So I spent a couple minutes making my own.  
This bracket should be tight enough to stay on the frame by itself however 2 mounting holes are provided should you wish to make it a little more permanent.  
This bracket has a cut out for the memory card slot and is based on the MOAB minimalistic approach.  
A simmilar bracket for the P3steel is coming soon.

20% infill worked perfectly for me with a .65mm shell on a .5mm nozzle.
requirements: RepRapDiscount Smart Controller as shown in the pictures (note the bad spelling at the bottom of the circuit board "SmatrConteallerD.PCB" Aurora 3D printer or similar Prusa i3 with a 7.65mm thick Frame. 4x M3x10mm bolts and M3 nuts for mounting the LCD module to the bracket. 2x M3x16mm Bolts and M3 nuts for mounting the bracket to the frame of the printer (optional)

comments.text: There's a little too much clearance between the central gear and planetary gears. Other than than printed really nicely.
comments.author: jgpaulso

comments.text: Yah the. 5mm clearance is a pretty bug number, but was used because I just wanted to get a successful gear print so I jacked the tolerance up to print well on my printerbot simple. Glad to hear it worked for someone else! Thanks for the comment. :)
comments.author: jgpaulso

comments.text: Update, I ended up making two of these and one fell apart. Well I kind of flexed the outer ring of the other in order to combine all the planetary gears around one center gear. Turns out it runs really really nice with 6 planetary gears. Don't know if you could update it and throw a couple more small gears in there (as best spaced out as you can), but it would work much better, with little work.
comments.author: Dan11i

comments.text: Im surprised it fell apart, ive put a good deal of stress, and even tried a tiny bit to get it apart and it hasnt, most likely because my printer is not super hi quality but, oh well. It can be adjusted since the file is remixable, and you can add a ton of extra gears if youd like! Would you like me to use the same specs and just add some more planets in just for you? :)
comments.author: jgpaulso

comments.text: I've noticed a decent amount of shrinkage from my replicator 2x. Around 1% when I measured it last, but that could have added to it some. When it did come it, two of the gears had worked closer together so it wasn't an even spread. it allowed the center gear to move a little more. Anyways the 6 planets works great. I see you added a file too for that. Thanks again.

description.text:
Its little Ponyo before her transformation.
Made this using Blender.

To make the first model shown I used the Replicator2 with PLA plastic (clear) 230 degrees on "medium" setting. I used supports and they were easily removed. I also scaled my model up from the original file size.
The second model shown I used the Replicator2 with PLA plastic (white) 200 degrees on "high" setting. I used supports (plus raft) and they were very easily removed. The model was scaled up from its original file size.

description.text: Firstly let me state this is not an original idea – recently a Beer Bottle Lock made the rounds on 3D printing news sites, stemming from an Instructables tutorial by JON-A-TRON (see http://www.instructables.com/id/Beer-Bottle-Lock/ for the original). However with Xmas fast approaching I wanted to design one for a bit of fun with my family. Simply print the 2 pieces out and use any small travel lock to secure that final beer (whether it's yours or someone else's!). Unlike the original by JON-A-TRON this design requires no screw. The dimensions are quite loose so that it should securely fit a wide variety of bottle shapes, if you don’t need this flexibility you might like to thicken 1 or 2 areas on the inside prior to printing. Sure it's could be snapped off, but this design is really just for a bit of fun - if you're genuinely worried about people stealing beer maybe you need to reconsider who your mates are ;) Follow how this was designed on my blog https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/category/beer-bottle-lock/

Print using 50% fill (for strength) and 2 mm layer height.

One problem that has often plagued users of the MakerBot Unicorn[1] is the long and confusing chain of tools required to go from a nice vector drawing to a G-Code file that can be plotted from ReplicatorG. mifga did an awesome tutorial[2] that made it possible to understand the steps needed to work all of these tools, but it was obvious that something better was needed. So, I made a mashup of scribbles.py[3] and the Egg-Bot Driver for Inkscape[4] to bring you the inkscape-unicorn extension for Inkscape! Once installed, this extension allows you to save files in "MakerBot Unicorn G-Code (*.gcode)" format! Learn more, download, and contribute at the GitHub page for this project: https://github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-unicorn If you're desperate, you can also download the zip file attached to this thing, but it is guaranteed to be out of date. Please get the latest version from GitHub. :) Thanks to langfordw for the original Unicorn Logo[5] used as an example on this Thing. UPDATES! I'm updating and adding features to this script as my first days for the February Thing-A-Day. Updates below:
  • Day 1, Release: http://thing-a-day.com/thing-a-day-2011-1-unicorn-pen-plotter-extens
  • Day 2, Registration and Homing: http://thing-a-day.com/new-features-for-inkscape-unicorn-pen-registr
  • Day 3, Copies and Continuous Plotting: http://thing-a-day.com/thing-a-day-2011-3-copies-and-continuous-plot
    • [1] Unicorn - http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-unicorn-pen-plotter-kit.html
    [2] mifga's Unicorn Tutorial - http://wiki.makerbot.com/unicorn-tutorial-01
    [3] scribbles.py - https://github.com/makerbot/Makerbot/tree/master/Unicorn/Scribbles%20Scripts
    [4] Egg-Bot Driver for Inkscape - http://code.google.com/p/eggbotcode/
    [5] Unicorn Logo by langfordw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4197

From the README: Install Copy the contents of src/ to your Inkscape extensions/ folder. Typical locations include: * OS X - /Applications/Inkscape.app/Contents/Resources/extensions * Linux - /usr/share/inkscape/extensions * Windows - C:\Program Files\Inkscape\share\extensions Usage * Size and locate your image appropriately: ** The CupCake CNC build platform size is 100mm x 100mm. ** Setting units to mm in Inkscape makes it easy to size your drawing. ** The extension will automatically attempt to center everything. * Convert all text to paths: ** Select all text objects. ** Choose Path | Object to Path. * Save as G-Code: ** File | Save a Copy. ** Select MakerBot Unicorn G-Code (*.gcode). ** Save your file. * Preview ** For OS X, Pleasant3D is great for this. ** For other operating systems... I don't know! * Print! ** Open your .gcode file in ReplicatorG ** Set up your Unicorn and pen. ** Center your build platform. ** Click the Build button!

comments.text: I generate the gcode using this plugin, then open the file in a word processor and use find and replace.  Be sure you set the pen up and pen down delays to different times so you can search and replace each command separately.  I replace the first pen down command with G4 P0, the following Dwell (G4 Pxxx) with M126 (laser on), the next Pen up with G4 P0, and lastly, final dwell with M127 (laser off).  Make sense?

description.text:
Siege catapult in Heroic Scale - version 1.0.
  • Working wheels
  • Swinging arm
  • firing motion if hooked up to rubber band, but the motion is clumsy.
    • TODO:
  • decorate (my children have lots of ideas...)
  • improve the firing arm
  • improve the firing basket

First of all, know what the pieces are:
  • body frames: the biggest two pieces, shaped kind of like the number 4. They look the same, but the decorations face different ways. Each has three circular holes and notches in various places.
  • body sides: two round-edged long pieces with two holes. Each end has a square notch.
  • body braces: two square-edged pieces with two long notches taken out of each end. They look kind of like plus signs.
  • axles: two long sticks with squares in the middle.
  • launch arm: kind of like a spoon attached to an axle. This is the thing that fires stuff if this were a real catapult.
  • washers: lots of little circles with square holes in them. six of these are hubs, which are the ones that human hands will touch when it's all done. They are otherwise all alike.
  • wheels: the four big circles with square holes in them.
  • overhead brace: like body braces, but one is shorter and has smaller notches in it.
    • Instructions:
  • cut it from 5mm stock (I use plywood)
  • clean it if you used wood. At the very least, you'll want to sand the edges of the four wheels down so they don't track soot on your play surface. With the exception of the hubs, you really don't need to sand the washers.
  • If you're going to paint or stain it, do it now. Do not paint or stain the washers at all if you want the wheels to turn. It's okay to paint/stain the hubs though.
  • Find two axles and four washers. Glue two washers onto each axle such that the axle goes through the washer, and the washer is stuck up against the square thingie in the middle. Look at the pictures for an idea of how this is supposed to go.
  • Do the same thing for the launch arm and two washers
  • Clamp these three items and set them aside to dry.
  • STOP. Wait for them to dry. Don't rush this or you may have problems later.
  • pair the two body frames with the body sides. Put the axles through the bottom holes and the launch arm through the top hole-- everything should fit together.
  • glue the body braces to the notches in the sandwiched body sides/body frame assembly
  • outside the body sides, add four washers to the protruding axles
  • outside the washers, glue the four wheels to the axles. Avoid getting glue on the washers-- the washers prevent the wheels from getting glued to the body, which will prevent turning :-)
  • glue the hubs to the axles (important) and wheels (less important). Again, try to avoid getting any glue on the body
  • clamp the whole thing together to dry. The wheels should be tight, but not so tight they can't move.
    [...]

remixed_from.title: Parametric ergonomic support for Apple Magic Trackpad

title: Parametric ergonomic support with wrist rest for Apple Magic Trackpad

description.text: This model is based on ex-nerd's parametric ergonomic support for Apple Magic Trackpad, which allows the trackpad to be used at an angle. I extended the platform to provide space to rest your wrist on. The length of the wrist rest is adjustable from 0 to 12cm. You can also customize the angle and handedness as in the original model. If you're looking for a similar thing for the Magic Trackpad 2, I have a work in progress here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2205899

Since this is a fairly large print, try to print with 15% infill or less if your printer can get away with it. I printed in colorFabb PLA/PHA on an Ultimaker 2.
0.2mm layer height at 100mm/s and 220ºC with 60ºC bed The correct dimensions for this model are: (W, D, H) 130.2, 218.0, 41.8 mm I also added rubber feet and a palm pad originally made for Kenisis Advantage keyboards.

Hi, Since I couldn't get any of Thingi cutters to slice correctly, I've made my own cat cookie cutters my gf for christmas, all of them are traced over pictures from google images. Enjoy :) This set fits on standard 200x200 bed, or you can split it in Slic3r to have single files. UPDATED 18.12.2014:

-Fixed some cat stuff like too thin tail
